column2: The paper investigates the chemical degradation mechanisms of PEDOT during reactive ion etching (RIE), focusing on its integration into conducting interpenetrating polymer network (C-IPN) actuators. It highlights the unexpectedly high etching rates of PEDOT-based materials due to a synergistic degradation process facilitated by the presence of oxygenated compounds in the polymer network. The study provides insights into the etching behavior of individual components like PEO, PTHF, and NBR, and proposes the use of fast etching processes for the fabrication of high-performance microactuators, demonstrating the operation of micro-beam actuators in air.

The paper details the development of highly conformable conducting polymer electrodes for in vivo recordings, focusing on a process to integrate PEDOT:PSS on flexible parylene substrates. These electrodes improve the quality of electrocorticography (ECoG) recordings with better spatial resolution and lower impedance compared to traditional metal electrodes. The fabricated electrodes are validated through in vivo experiments in rats, demonstrating their potential for less invasive and more effective neural interfacing applications.

The paper reports on the development of transparent microelectrode arrays (MEAs) utilizing PEDOT:PSS electrodes for simultaneous electrophysiology and advanced optical microscopy. The electrodes, optimized for low impedance and high transparency, enable high signal-to-noise ratio recordings of neuronal action potentials and support calcium imaging with minimal light-induced artefacts. These MEAs are compatible with super-resolution microscopy, paving the way for integrated electrophysiological and optical studies in neuroscience.

This research demonstrates the development of flexible micro-electrocorticography (μECoG) arrays using PEDOT:PSS electrodes that are compatible with ultra-high magnetic field MRI up to 9.4 T. The arrays enable high-resolution neural recordings and minimal MRI distortion, allowing for simultaneous electrophysiology and advanced brain imaging. The study highlights the μECoG arrays' capability to combine high-resolution electrophysiology with MRI, providing insights into brain function.

The paper presents a novel fabrication process for conducting polymer microelectrode arrays (MEAs) based on poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) doped with poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) and insulated with parylene-C. The MEAs demonstrate low impedance and high-quality electrophysiological signal recording capabilities. The method involves photolithography and a mechanical peel-off process, allowing patterning on various substrates without harsh chemical treatment. Validation was achieved through in vitro recordings from rat hippocampus slices, demonstrating the potential of these MEAs for neuroscience applications and drug screening.
